Sentencas: The performance of anode-supported solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC) was evaluated in synthetic coal gas containing HCl in the temperature range 650-850 degrees C. Exposure to up to 800 ppm HCl resulted in reversible poisoning of the Ni/zirconia anode by chlorine species adsorption, the magnitude of which decreased with increased temperature.
Titulo: Reversible poisoning of nickel/zirconia solid oxide fuel cell anodes by hydrogen chloride in coal gas

Sentencas: Performance losses increased with the concentration of HCl to 100 ppm, above which losses were insensitive to HCl concentration.
Titulo: Reversible poisoning of nickel/zirconia solid oxide fuel cell anodes by hydrogen chloride in coal gas

Sentencas: Neither cell potential, nor current density had any effect on the extent of poisoning.
Titulo: Reversible poisoning of nickel/zirconia solid oxide fuel cell anodes by hydrogen chloride in coal gas

Sentencas: No evidence was found for long-term degradation that can be attributed to HCl exposure.
Titulo: Reversible poisoning of nickel/zirconia solid oxide fuel cell anodes by hydrogen chloride in coal gas

Sentencas: Similarly, no evidence of microstructural changes or formation of new solid phases as a result of HCl exposure was found.
Titulo: Reversible poisoning of nickel/zirconia solid oxide fuel cell anodes by hydrogen chloride in coal gas

Sentencas: From thermodynamic calculations, solid nickel chloride phase formation was shown to be highly unlikely in coal gas containing HCl.
Titulo: Reversible poisoning of nickel/zirconia solid oxide fuel cell anodes by hydrogen chloride in coal gas

Sentencas: The presence of HCl at even the highest anticipated concentrations in coal gas would minimally increase the volatility of nickel.
Titulo: Reversible poisoning of nickel/zirconia solid oxide fuel cell anodes by hydrogen chloride in coal gas
